projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

keywords.term: James -- I, -- King of England, 1566-1625 -- Poetry -- Early works to 1800.

div.p: LACHRYMAE Jn Augustiſsimi Monarchae, JACOBI .I. MAGNAE BRITANNIAE, FRANCIAE, & HIBERNIAE, REGIS: receſſu de patriae ſuae SCOTIAE in ANGLOrum fines.
EDINBƲRGI, Excudebat THOMAS FINLASON, Auguſt. REG. MAJEST. Typographus. 1617.

div.head: LACHRYMAE, Jn Augustiſsimi Monarchae, JACOBI .I. MAGNAE BRITANNIAE, FRANCIAE, & HIBERNIAE, REGIS: receſſu de patriae ſuae SCOTIAE in ANGLOrum fines.

lg.l:
SPEs leuibus malefida alis, dubij
que labores
Et nunquam triſti riſas fine felle ſereni,

Quae
que rapís cupidas ſublimis gloria mentes,
'''Quid stabile eſt? quid perpetuum? Siene omnis in auras

Sicne abiit fortunarecens? rupto
que tenore
Mutauit ſubito tot gaudia, tot lamentis?
O dolor! o lachrymae o gemitus! evanida rerum
Somnia! & in fragili fluitantia vota phaſelo!

Nuper at (ah memini,) Phoebum
que
novem
que ſorores

Sollicitabam ardens animi; dignum
que tuoruni
Plauſibus, & feſto reditu REX magne, parabam
Promere Pierio tenuatum in vertice carmen:
Sponte ſùa noſtris lauri cecidere capillis,

Jrrepſit
que nocens taxus; (miſerabile dictu,)
Sponte ſua cytharae manibus dum fila retendo,

Flebile neſcio quid chorde gemuere; ſoni
que
Diſcordes strepitus, digiti elicuere trementes.
Nonne • i • t •••• ius, tali ſub tempore ſtetus,

Et tempeſtiuos gemitus, planctuſ
que dediſſe?
'''Non bene ſeit ſer vare molum: nunc omen iniquum

Experior, vacuae
que luo deliria mentis.

Inde mihi hae lachrymae, hi fletus, miſeranda
que fluxit

In numeros noua cur ameos, vix plectra jocos
que
Depofui manibus, ſubijtcur a anxia luctu:
Et dolor: & triſtis non unica noctis imago.

Nam
que
Caledoniis quae lux affulſeratoris,
Candida lux vixdum coelo quum viſa coruſcum
Exeruiſſe jubar, caput atris nubibus abdit;
Damnatura diem: tenebris ſic omnia late
Circumfuſajacent; poſtquam tibi Magne redire
Anglorum in terras, patriae de finibus almae,

Jam fixum, immotum
que ſedet: nulla ahne rogantum
Supplicia avertiſſe queunt? miſerere precamur,
Et duris faciles adverte o quaeſtibus aures
Quid deſiderium Scotis JACOBE relinquis?
Phoebe mane, lux alma mane, radiate mane Sol.
Qu • i—ter in gelido vates Oeagrius Haemo,
Amiſſa Euridice, plectro tentauit eburno

Fila lyrae: numeroſ
que dedit, que is ipſa ferarum

Turba ſuper gemuit; viſae
que ad carmina quercus
Suſpiraſſe diu; & tacitum ſenſiſſe dolorem,
Humida ſuffuſis lachrymarum flumine venis,
Quamuis continuo duriſsima ſaxa lapillo;

Talis ego: talem
que refert mea Muſa dolorem,
Aſsiduis turbata malis; muſa obruta fluctu
Curarum, duris quam ſaepe exercita fatis

Triſtities afflixit humi: propius
que ſalutis
Spem poſuiſſe omnem fecit. Jam victa dolore
Pectora ſubſidunt propiora pericula fatis
• ūſquam; vix ſi • nda meam decumana carinam

Verberet aequoreae
que latus cogat dare Brumae:
Heic ego Amycleos ſupplex nam in vota vocarem
Deprenſus pelago fratres; tibi Iupiter undae
Votivum auderem taurum promittere, ſalv •
Si modo finitimam liceat contingere arenam.

Nunc ſpes interciſa omnis: penituſ
que reſultat
Maeſtitiae mihi ſumma dies: late omnia, late

Jlluvie, ſqualore, ſitu, macie
que feruntur.
O divi, quidnam hoc quod per tot fata paratis?
Mortalemne ſedet totis deperdere telis?

In
que vicem variare iras? date vulnera cuncta
Si qua ſuper; noſtris IACOBUM haud tollite terris.
Jbo ego, & Iſmario, ſi quis mihi ſpiritus Orpheo
Flebiliora canam. certe me ſaxa dolentem

Audierint; ſylvae
que etiam, pecudeſ
que ſequutae
Accedent lachrymis; & quae stridentibus alis
Aeratranſmittet liquidum, vaga forte volucris
Ingemet, & motae ſuſpendens verber a pennae,
Damnabit ſuperos noſtras miſerata querelas
Quid tamen o ſuperos? non hos miſere dolores

Coelicolae nobis; ne
que enim tam ferrea diuis
Pectora, tu ſolus (Rex) hac de parte Prometheus.
Quid fingis grauiora tuis? duram exu • mentem
Dum licet in medijs reditum an molire querelis?
Phoebe mane, lux alma mane, radiate mane Sol.
Vix bis plena vage co • erunt cornua Lunae,
Quum venit, & refugit: necdum expectatus, abire
Rex JACOBE paras. Anne • o promittere divum eſt
Fallere? & (heu!) fraudare tuos felicibus horis?
Non ita cui Clariae laurus, & limina parent
Muſarum: cytharam qui pectine temperat aureo
Ortygiae inviſit lucos: ubi cornea circum

Creteſ
que Dryopeſ
que
fremant altaria laeti.
Nonita Tartarei prudens matronatyranni,
Septima quum exeruit formoſos Cynthia vultus
Trinacriae aſcendit colles: quam plurimacingit

Hinc at
que hinc Dryas; & per colla fluente capillo
Ventilet ut niveas Zephyri ſinit aura papillas:
Ipſa vel Oebalium pueri de nomine florem,
Narciſſumve legit ſparſum vel ſanguine A donin,
Aut Caltham nitidi pendentem a lumine Phoebi:
Que is calathos onerans, Stygii reminiſcitur ignis;
Conſcia nec pri ••• jam damnat prata rapinae.

Te quo
que tangit amor patriae, ne
que enim horrida cautes
Edidit, aut Getula tibi dedit uber a tigris;
Sed te Pegaſeis enutrivere ſub antris

Caſtalia de valle dea: Charitum
que
decore
Nuda trias, laetos oculis afflauit honores.
Hanc ſine nos ſpem ferre tui. ſi crimina noſtrae
Tot meruere pati, Rex invictiſsime, poenas,
Quin luimus? mora longareo mors altera, at o jam
Si quatibi ſuper at ſub pectore curatuorum,
Phoebe mane; lux alma mane, radiate mane Sol.
Flumina quae leni vitreum properatis in aequor;
Agmine; & o blando quae diuidis alma ſuſurro

Dulce melos, nemorum
que comis interſtrepis aura:
Veſtra Caledonius ſi gaudia Jupiter, & tot
Laetitiae bona ſigna, pium teſtantia amoren •
Accepit; picta vectus quando ipſe phaſelo,

Naiadum plaudente choro, Zephyro
que
canente,

Trans
que
Taum, Forthae
que
ſinum: ſi magna voluptas

Laetandi fuerat, nunc fit quo
que tanta dolendi.
Mecum una gemitus, & ſingultantia verba,
Mecum una ingentes, lachymarum ecfundite rivos.
Noſtra ſalus, & veſter amor, pia cura Deorum,

Spes
que hominum (hei) patrias IACOBUS deſerit or as.
Dux Ferguſinde, ſi animum pia stringit imago
Antiquae patriae, nec tota evanuit illa
Pectoris arcano quondam tibi clauſa receſſu
SCOTIA necte morae cauſas; nonſceptra relinquas
ANGLA, nec ut ſiſtus Scotorum ſemper in oris,
("Quanquam o! nam magnum quod habet graue crinis
Tempus inane peto; dum ſe componere tantis [amare?)

Curarum mens aegra queat quando
que procellis:
Et diſcat graviora pati. Venaticus ex qu •
Tempore, cervino f ſitientia labra cruore
Proluit; & longis durauit curfibus artus;
Collibus adſueſcit: donec robuflior annis,
Audeat aerij ſuperare cacumina montis;
Et ſeruare dolos, & fraudem fallere fraude.
Tum laetus ruit in campos, & culmina nota,
Et domino obſequitur, curſum ſeu ſiſtere poſcat,

Corripere audito, ſpacium ſeu deni
que ſigno.
Me certe tantus latum hoc protruſit in aequor
Triſtitiae non ante dolor; ſed enim advena primum

Melpomenes abs
que arte lyramnunc tangere cogor:

Damnatum
que choris Mufarum aſſumere plectrum
Jn vitus jubeor. non hac non triſtia Phoebus,
Diſceſſus ſed Magnetuus, mihi carmina mandat:
Carmina quae rapidas utinam violentia in auras
Diſcerpat Boreae; & madidis Notus humidus alis
Immergat pelago, qua turbidus Adria ſaevit,
Aut qua Scylla ferox canibus praecincta marinis,
Auditur S • iculo raucum latrare profundo.
Jrrita ſint. fruſtratantas fudiſſe querelas
Rex JACOBE ferar. ſed quid mea vulnera ſpecto?
Phoebe mane, lux almamane, radiate mane Sol.
Ahne fugis? per ego has lachrimas, per gaudiateſtor
Quae data ſunt quoniam ſubito reddenda fuerunt,
Nil Ferguſiacis viſum crudelius oris.
Tu mihi Sol teſtis, tu pernox conſcia Luna,

Per
que Polum certo remeantia ſydera curſu.
Non etenim tu ſolus abis; tecum omnia tecum

Ire parant. Muſae
que graves, & cantor Apollo,
Et castus veneris puer, & veneranda leporum

Quid ſuper eſt niſi triſte Chaos miſeranda
que rerum
Jn luctu facies? & conjurata malorum
Tempeſtas, emiſſa Erebi de vallibus atris?
Ecce tibi modo purpureos quae Daedala flores

Sternebat Tellus, maeret deſerta; ſuoſ
que
Squalida damnauit felici gramine campos.
Flava Ceres, miſero non reſponſura colono,
Maesta ſedet; qualis Sicula quum lampada ab Aetna
Accendens, cunctis natam quaeſiuit ab oris.
Ingemit obſcuris memorum Dryas abdita in umbris.

Rura
que laſciuae ſua deſeruere Napeae.
Naiades lacrymis fontes auxiſſe feruntur.
Et PAN obſtreperas ſaxo alliſiſſe cicutas,
Jpſe ego, ceu campis demens errabat Eleis

BELLEROPHON cor vſ
que ſuum depaſtus, inani
Complebam infaelix reſonantia ſaxa querela,
Qua ſubit ANDREIAE felices coerula portu •
Doris, & expaſsis in vitat in oſcula palmis.

Surda
que ceu noſtros audirent ſaxa dolores
Damnabam. nunc inde pedem revocare volebam
Perditus, in deſerta procul; ſine fine beatos.
Exclamans Zephyros, quite REX optime circum
Leniter, & motis applaudant ſaepius alis.

In
que alto reſidens viridantis gramine prati,
Collibus aut ſolis, aut vorticibus praeruptis,
Pectoris arcanos heu vulnera dura dolores
Mente pia revocans; in fletum nubila ſolvi,
Et ferrugineis obduci clara tenebris

Lumina, ſplendentes
que oculos Hyperionis aurei
Optabam: divis, non haec in vota ſecundis.

Nam tibi ſtat, fixum
que animo manet, ire beatas

ANGLORUM in treras. heu ſors. adverſa
que fata.
PHOEBE mane, lux alma mane, radiate mane Sol
Sed quid ego haec, ſurdas tantum ſi verberat aures
Haec vox caſſa deum? legum ſeruanda poteſtas
Ilicet, & quicquid ſuperi mens prouida regis
Conſilio arcano fieri decreverat olim,

Non lachrymis, planctu
que hominum diſſolvitur. aut vi
Frangitur aduerſa. stat Ahenea turris in auras
Fatorum titulo, cui lex adjuncta neceſſieſt;
Quam nec Hyperboreo properās de monte procella,
Aeolio aut rapidus laxatus carcere turbo,
Aut pelagi ira ferox pugnantibus excita ventis
Deſtruat; aut vincat: ſic inconcuſſa reſiſtit,

Tot coeli, pelagi
que minis. perge omine dextro,
Perge igitur, tua qua revocant te Maxime fata.
Et quamvis patris hinc titulîs te oppugnet, & Anglas
Sevocet in terras; ubi dulcia gaudia conjunx
Gratetur reduci, & chariſsima pignora CARLUS
Currat in amplexus: patriae illinc tangat imago

Mentem animi: tu REX vince alto pectore utrun
que
Plus tibi ſit patriae dici & ſimul eſſe parentem.
Inde tibi ſurget decus immortale coronae;
Jnde tuos cinget viridant • fronde capillos
Gloria; & aeternum statuet tibi fama trophaeum.
Caetera ſint miſere plebi, & communia vulgo:
Hoc proprium REX magne tibi: quo haud altior vllu •

Extulit os ſacrum coelo, tenebras
que reſolvit
Bellorum, & longa populos ſub pace beauit:
Si Ferguſiacos numeres ab origine patres.
Haec lux immenſum radiantia tela per orbem
Deſperſit, Sol Eoo e gurgite promit
Siderios vultus, & qua caput occulit undis
Occiduis, feſſo ſolvens temone jugales;
Qua campos Libiae, naſcenti & conſcia Nilo

Qua
que fugit Boreae torpentes frigore terras.

Arva
que
Rhiphaeis multum damnanda Pruinis,
Si non luce tua, & radiis propioribus Arcti.

Frigoribus, triſti
que hyemi ſolatia ferres.
Fortius huc igitur radios, & ſpicula vibra;

Vt
que
Calidoniae, tepeant face frigora Brumae.
Hoc vnum praecor o, ſi non licet omnia, quum jam
Phoebe abeas; lux alma abeas; radiate abeas Sol.
Claude reluctantes tenebroſe in carcere fratres.
Ventorum o domitor; vaſti & ſuper inſice mentis
Fragmina; nec madidis Auſter petat aera pennis,
Obducens picea totas caligine terras;
Nec ſine ut effuſis Boreae; inclementia habenis
Bacchetur per inane furens; nec turbidus Eurus

Acris illatis circum ſtrepat vndi
que campis
Horriſonum: ſoli Zephyro ſ •• copia coeli.
Hic ſemper placidis JACOBO aſsibilet auris,
Dum Thameſis ripas, & paſcua grata Camaenis
Ille redux teneat; coniux vhi blanda Favoni,
Jnter diffuſas per candida colla Napaeas
Ceſariem flauam, blandum ſpirantibus inſtat
Floribus: & vario depingit prata colore.
Hic vellet miti Zephyrus ſtabularier antro,
Si qua fides verbis; & ſe putat eſſe beatum
Si quando Aenariae liquit diſcedere campis:
Coniugis ut fuſus gremio, viridantia Tempe
Inter, & aeternos Thameſaei ruris honores,

Jnſpiret molles animas; blandum
que
JACOBO
Murmuret: & dulci ludat circum ora ſuſurro.
Sic quicquid nimio vel adurit prata calore,
Frigore vel triſti ſurgentes deterit harbas,
Exul erat: Schythiae gelidis ſeſe occulat oris

Triſtis hyems; Lybiae
que
procul deſerta peragret
Aeſtus, & inſani poſitos ſub ſydere Cancri.
Sic o Magne parens, cuius tremefacta verendo
Judicis a vultu, cum juſtam accenderis iram,
Subſidit Tellus; quam nil quod jam eſtve, fuitve,

Vel quo erit quando
que latet; qui cuncta tenore
Perpetuo ſtabilita regis; Regum altior omni

Imperio ſolus; qui ſceptra, decuſ
que
TIARAE
Regibus, & magnum prae aliis largiris honorem;

Vtte vnum agnoſcant Dominum, patri
que benigno
Supplicibus votis, & mentis thure litarent;
Sic o Magne parens, famulum dignare favore

Vſ
que tuo: ſceptrum
que bea: reduciſ
que vt euntis,
Oſtendas populo faelicia Principis ora.
His certo immenſum nutu qui temperat orbem
Annuet; haec rata vota dabit. Tu dirige tutos
Saxonidum in terras conſtanti tramite greſſus:

Vſ
que tamen patriae memor o REX maxime amatae.

Jam
que vale. lachrymis in moeſta cadentibus ora,
Plura loqui gemitus vetat, & dolor altus, in imo
Pectore ſuppreſſus; qui dum ſe non capit ipſum,
Nec questus capit ipſe ſuos: confuſus, & vnum hoc,
Dum grauiora parat, magno de vulnere anhelat;
PHOEBE vale, lux alma vale, radiate vale Sol.
